I'm as right wing as they come, but this is bullshit.

It's easy to verify that there is a government by observing the effects of 
it, in the same way gravity is a real thing we can verify by dropping an 
object; we see the evidence of its existence, even if we can't sense the 
thing itself.

Anarchist society doesn't work. We need a government. It doesn't have to be 
big at all, but it must do a few things in order to maintain capitalism.

Capitalism isn't some magical construct that materializes out of thin air. 
It's a system that the British invented which seeks to minimize coercive 
force by making people accountable to each other in fair trade deals, then 
establishing a series of public institutions that lock each other's powers 
down and allowing the people to closely inspect each of them and change the 
people seated in them as they see fit. Therefore, capitalism and democracy 
are closely connected. You actually can't have one without the other, and 
we see plenty evidence of this throughout history.

The problem is that you can't eliminate coercive force. You need it to 
uphold capitalism itself. If people can just steal from you, they don't 
care if you "shun them"; they've got everything they need. At that point, 
you need coercive force, i.e. a prison system and a judicial system, to 
stop them.

You also need defense of the realm. You cannot reasonably expect the people 
to rally when enemies are invading by themselves; you need something to 
defend them. This is why we have police, firefighters, and the military.

Capitalism will naturally tend towards monopoly if you allow the private 
control of infrastructure, as the game Monopoly clearly shows. Now I know 
Monopoly is some kind of propaganda because it assumes that you are coerced 
into staying on the roads and the hotels on which you land each turn. This 
is of course false - assuming the roads are open to anybody at any time. If 
a private entity can control infrastructure, this isn't the case, and 
capitalism breaks down.

This is why there is literally, as far as I know, not a single country on 
Earth where the main infrastructure - like power grids, plumbing, 
railroads, and roads - are controlled by a private institution. It just 
doesn't work. It's suicide for a free society to allow that, and we're 
seeing exactly why this is the case in the US right now simply because 
we've allowed ISP's to control internet lines.

You can't rely on anarchy to maintain capitalism. It just won't work. You 
just get outlaws, and marauders, and people going into gangs and beating 
each other up. Even in the presence of some coercive force we still see 
these kinds of groupings. The local gang around the street doesn't give a 
fuck about you think of it as long as you pay your dues. The only way you 
can stop it is calling the police. Without government, and without coercive 
force in the form of tax money to fund this police force, you wouldn't have 
it.

We must strive to make sure that the majority of the people controls the 
coercive force that is available, and we must have it available to us. It's 
the only way.﻿

What you're talking about here is a unicorn.  A stateless society would 
remain stateless for like 10 seconds.  Or it would be stateless 
in-name-only, as a conglomerate of defense companies, arbitration 
companies, financial companies, and energy companies uses its power to 
apply the "rules" however it sees fit.  Or they just use their private 
militaries to say "fuck your rules, this is our house now."

Kinda like they do now, just without the middle-man that occasionally sides 
with the public rather than with the most powerful.

Most of the abuses of government come from the corrupting influence of Big 
Money.  The answer isn't to shred the government, it's to shield it from 
corporate influence as much as possible.  

There are lots of ways to go about accomplishing that.  I like the idea of 
eliminating congressional elections, in favor of a random sampling of the 
population to serve limited terms in order to eliminate the practice of 
lobbying and to make government more representative of the people.

I like the idea of a citizens' income as the primary inflationary measure, 
and I think it the only fair and sustainable way to distribute the 
unprecedented wealth that is being created as a result of job-replacing 
tech.

But there are many ideas.  Statelessness just isn't feasible, and I don't 
think it'd be particularly fun even if it were. ﻿

Voluntarism sounds good on paper, but can it actually work when taking into 
account human nature? I remember a study where they had a group of people 
sitting around a table in the open. Everyone was given an amount of money. 
The experiment was conducted in rounds where the subjects were told if 
everyone put in a dollar then everyone would receive a return on their 
investment equal to the total pot. They had the option of putting money in 
or keeping it and not doing it. It was found that if everyone was were 
watched by the others they would all put their share of money in and 
everyone would receive the maximum pay out. However, if they put barriers 
between the people so you couldn't see who put in and who withheld then one 
of the subjects (if not more than one) would always begin to hold back his 
share to profit from others without putting his in. In effect, you will 
always have people in society that will not do what's best for the whole of 
society. This seems to suggest voluntarism is unviable.﻿

My current view: Questions of ethics ARE determinined via consequences, as 
it's only in relation to consequences and a broader (and unlimited) 
perspective that we get to determine whether something constitutes 'theft', 
'rape' etc.. No-one is arguing that stealing is universally preferable as a 
rule (this is contradictory based on the definition of the word 'stealing' 
since it's logically impossible to advocate stealing from oneself (it 
wouldn't be stealing)), the question is whether any specific action 
constitutes 'stealing'.. and the extent to which one can account for 
anything in the world is dependent on the rapidly expanding scientific 
bodies of knowledge, neuroscience, psychology etc.. So what constitutes 
violations of the NAP are determined with reference to vast bodies of 
knowledge to which there is asymetry amongst persons. This asymetry 
legitimates the use of force in instances where a party who have superior 
knowledge use force in order to prevent another party from a serious 
detrimental consequence that they, with the time and capacity to aquire 
further knowledge, would not choose. In such an instance the initiation of 
force would be shown to be moral by the demonstration that one party had 
acted upon a superior understanding of the situation. The NAP is therefore 
not universally true in and of itself (unless it's from a god's eye view 
(it assumes a metaphysical perspective and no such perspective exists, 
which puts it in religious/fundamentalist territory)), it's merely more 
desireable that people do things voluntarily but for this to be possible 
the demands of any particular circumstance have to accomodate it. So this 
is entirely dependent on the systems that are possible to put in place 
through which society is constituted. Therefore it's wrong to argue that 
libertarians shouldn't focus on the means through which a voluntary society 
could function, the means are EVERYTHING. This is a technological issue, 
the question is how to put in place systems that maximise liberty. Ranting 
about the government being 'evil' whilst choosing to live in a statist 
society is misleading/misguided when the only way to show the value of 
principles of liberty is to show how liberty can be maximised, which is 
technologically dependent.﻿

Well yes, it is necessary that some people procreate.

But who it is that is doing the procreating matters quite a lot. Ideally, 
you want intelligent and responsible people procreating. You dont want 
stupid and irresponsible people procreating.

The reasons for this are that A) Intelligent and responsible parents will 
have better parenting practices than stupid and irresponsible ones and B) 
Intelligence, and the traits which comprise responsibility, empathy, the 
ability to defer gratification, cooperativeness and so on, are all somewhat 
heritable. If you take IQ as a reasonable proxy for intelligence, that is 
about 75% heritable amongst adults. The children of stupid and 
irresponsible parents will be disposed by both their upbringing and their 
genes to greater levels of economic dependency, criminality and a whole 
host of other social ills. 

So the quality of future generations, and by extension the prosperity of 
society as a whole, in no small part depends on who it is who is having the 
most children.

Intelligent people are generally more economically productive, resulting in 
a non trivial correlation between income and intelligence. So paying those 
who cannot support children themselves to have them basically means paying 
dumb people to have more kids. This is a generalisation, and exceptions 
will exist, but in the aggregate, subsidising the fertility of the poor 
means lowering the average IQ of future generations. 

Responsible people dont have children they know at the time they have no 
means of paying for, expecting others to foot the bill. So those who choose 
to avail themselves of the welfare provisions that allow them to have 
children they themselves cannot pay for, by relying on taxpayer's money, 
are disproportionately going to be irresponsible. 

Baring this in mind, what do present welfare policies achieve? Well they 
subsidise stupid and irresponsible people to have children, by forcing 
intelligent and responsible people to pay for their children, thereby 
depriving intelligent and responsible people of money which they may have 
used to raise more children of their own.

Therefore, present welfare policy has a negative effect on both the quality 
of parenting and the innate intelligence and responsibility of future 
generations. And whilst the continuation of civilisation does indeed 
require the raising of children, it requires the raising of children who 
are likely to grow into productive and law abiding adults, not the raising 
of children who will likely grow up to be a social and economic burden. 
Welfare policies do not increase the number of the former, they increase 
the number of the latter.﻿

I am a Minarchist. I lean towards a very small, limited government, but I 
can't wrap my head around no government at all. Though I do understand and 
accept the moral and philosophical justifications for completely 
eliminating it.

The issues I have are with just a few services that I can't see adequately 
being provided by the free market. The biggest one, the military. First 
off, how would it be funded precisely? Would there be multiple private 
militaries? People in each community can choose to pay for them or not, but 
if people don't pay, they still benefit from the protection of the 
military. So, beyond a sense of honor, why would anyone voluntarily pay for 
it? They'll get the benefit no matter. Which means no one would end up 
paying, or too few. The logistics of managing and overseeing the military 
cause me concern too. I think a government is necessary to fund and manage 
a purely defensive military.

Next would be Police and courts. Mostly the same issues with funding. The 
logistics of it don't sync up very well for me and I can see many conflicts 
arising with multiple competing police forces, though it could work if 
there was a government around purely to establish baseline laws, only the 
most basic. Simple examples, don't murder, don't steal. Basic stuff like 
that. Courts are necessary to settle contractual disputes and other 
matters. In a complex society, they are essential. 

The last one is actually that catching memes... but what about the roads? 
And don't get me wrong, I think most roads can be entirely privatized for 
general travel around the country, between towns, highways, bridges, etc... 
but inside towns, especially in residential areas. I can't see it working 
too well. How would a toll road function if the road is right in front of 
my home? Also, what about sidewalks? It seems highly impractical for towns 
to have privately funded roads, unless there is a different method of 
paying for them other than tolls.

"Science advances by extending personal physics to universal physics."
True in a sense, but this is not the source of scientific merit.  The merit 
of science stems from its methodological testing of theories 
(personal physics), thereby separating mere speculation from demonstrable 
relationships.  In this way science has aided in the building of a 
comprehensible and predictable understanding of the world.  This, in turn, 
allows more effective use of our rational minds, as rational thought can 
be no more valid than the assumptions it acts upon. 

"In the same way, morality advances by extending personal ethics to 
universal ethics"
The above two quotes seem to justify the universal ethics by comparing it 
to science, but the described 'universal ethics' has (to my knowledge) no 
methodology to separate ethics of sheer speculation from those of 
demonstrable value.  Without this, ethics remain in the realm of personal 
subjective beliefs (like religion).  It is my hope that the transition 
from  science to ethics was a rhetorical mechanic to introduce your idea of 
universal ethics, and not an effort to bolster the merit of your universal 
ethic via an indefensible analogy to science and the utility that comes 
from the demonstrable relations it discovers.﻿

You make the comparison between scientific laws and moral rules as if they 
are similar. Just as our scientific understanding is applied universally, 
so must our moral understanding. We could have a discussion about how 
science describes what is, and morality prescribes what ought to be, but 
I'm just going to grant that they are similar.
Scientific laws are only true under a given set of circumstances. For 
example, it is true the speed of light is 299,792,458 m/s, but only under 
the circumstance of it being in a vacuum. And theories of gravity work well 
until you apply them to the circumstances of black holes. I'm pointing this 
out because you seem to think applying something universally requires that 
it be true under every set of circumstances. That's not what science does.
Physicists accept General Relativity as valid under some circumstances, but 
not others (e.g., black holes and particle physics). So can the NAP be 
valid under some circumstances, but not others? For example, it is wrong to 
initiate force by pushing someone out of the way in order to be first in 
line for concert tickets. But what if we change the circumstances? Let's 
say someone initiates force by pushing someone out of the way in order save 
a child from being hit by a car. Is this immoral? Both situations have an 
initiation of force by pushing. We've just changed the goal of the person 
doing the pushing and the outcome of the pushing. So if the initiation of 
force is always wrong no matter the circumstances, then it would be immoral 
to save the child by pushing. But if we accept the NAP the same way 
scientists accept physical laws, then it could be that there are at least 
some circumstances in which violating the NAP is not always immoral.﻿

Wow, assuming that just because someone is an atheist that they are likely

During this conference, a panel of 16 of the very top living philosophers

and Steven Weinberg, come to the point of talking about the necessity of 
universal healthcare, and everyone's heads start bobbing up and down about 
how they agree with this. These people are way beyond atheists, they are 
experts in the scientific method as it is commonly practiced, and widely 
respected as top thinkers.

There is no link that I have noticed between intelligence/scientific 
approach/empiricism and consistent support for the NAP. Why? Because the 
NAP is a personal preference, not a universal preference, and voluntayism 
is about opting in, not about "truth". The exception, I find, is that there 
is good evidence that prosperity is best supported, in most cases, by 
peaceful trade instead of redistribution (aka plunder + stated 
justification). For some reason, the majority of highly rational people 
aren't interested in reviewing this evidence as presented in e.g. Ridley's *The 
Rational Optimist* . Or, if they have reviewed it, find it an insufficient 
basis to support peaceful trade over plunder.

Claiming to have jumped the is/ought gap with rationality is not rational 
that I have seen. So even someone as intelligent as Stef is getting caught 
in the web of murky thinking. Philosophy is not only *not easy* but it is 
insanely difficult in this world that is so deeply steeped in violence, and 
the ability to deal well with abstraction (sometimes confused with 
"intelligence") seems to provide as many pitfalls as advantages in 
approaching it.

In any case, I obviously agree with Stef on the efficacy of the NAP 
(regardless of his confused implications that he has no interest in 
efficacy due to the matter having been already resolved by means of 
rhetorical tautology), and he does a nice job here of laying out the 
typical sales pitch for the NAP. However, I am unsure about why he would 
conjecture that a person like Thunderf00t would support the NAP... few 
scientists and intellectuals do. Science, atheism, and philosophy amount to 
religion for many people. How? Because they have blind faith in them to one 
extent or another. Only skepticism can yield deeper truths, and anyone who 
claims they have certainly valid first principles is not skeptical enough

So scientific rationality and determining how it works is anarchic, but you 
say it is certainly based on Aristotle's and Socrates' views of thought? 
That is like saying that the U.S. is anarchic but it is based on Obama's 
and Harry Reid's views of the constitution. 

I'm all for avoiding contradictions in thinking, and the Greeks did some 
nice early work in this area, but Wittgenstein seems to have done a good 
job showing that definitions are the real heart of the matter of 
philosophy, rather than logic. Logic is easy, but definitions and 
interpretations can create irresolvable difficulty if our terms are claimed 
to be more powerful than they are in containing objective truth. For 
example, where is the clear definition of "preference" and how can a 
clearly subjective input be quantified? That is where ethics detaches from 
science, and there is nothing in Aristotle that can bypass this... even he 
said, in *Nicomachean Ethics* that, as wiki states, "Concerning accuracy 
and whether ethics can be treated in an objective way, Aristotle points out 
that the "things that are beautiful and just, about which politics 
investigates, involve great disagreement and inconsistency, so that they 
are thought to belong only to convention and not to nature". For this 
reason Aristotle claims it is important not to demand too much precision, 
like the demonstrations we would demand from a mathematician, but rather to 
treat the beautiful and the just as "things that are so for the most part". 
We can do this because people are good judges of what they are acquainted 
with, but this in turn implies that the young (in age or in character), 
being inexperienced, are not suitable for study of this type of political 
subject." Oh, yeah, that sounds like rock hard science and rational 
certainty to me! ;)﻿

So, this is a tangential issue related to your post, but I wanted to 
respond to your assertion that there's a philosophical contradiction in god 
passing judgment or even killing someone and such actions being immoral for 
humans. For definitions sake, I'm talking about a supreme deity that is 
responsible for the creation of the entire universe. Both of us, I think, 
would agree with a homesteading/labor mixing view of property rights. If an 
entire universe were to exist entirely because of someone's labor, wouldn't 
that mean that he owns that universe? You might object to this on the 
grounds that humans are really important, but wouldn't a god like that be 
even more superior than we are to bacteria? If we recognize a qualitative 
difference between humans and cattle that allows us to use them as food, 
when all we do is corral them, couldn't god design whatever purpose for he 
wants for that which he created through sheer force of will?

Not only this, but Colossians, for example points out that such a deity 
would also be holding the universe together as we speak. So, a god creates 
and continues to support the existence of something, but he isn't allowed 
authority over it? Meanwhile, if I put a fence up around some land, mow the 
lawn, and build a house, that's homesteading? It seems to me this is a 
double standard, not the other way around.﻿

to the rest of the world, just so everyone is aware of that fact) while 
liberals tend to want to guarantee that same utopia via government force,

A true free society must have rules, but not rulers. The best example to 
verify this is when people play a board game. There are intrinsic rules to 
the game that the participants must abide to (but in no way are they forced 
to) in order for the game to be enjoyable. It is mutually beneficial for 
all players to follow the rules even though there is no ruler to enforce 
them. Of course it is possible to cheat, but then the other players would 
probably agree to kick the cheater out of the game. If he refuses, then 
nobody would want to play with the cheater anymore. Simple solution to a 
simple problem, no need for a ruler to forcefully enforce the rules of the 
game.﻿

I am a libertarian, but the argument that a moral argument's validity is 
independent of consequence via the analogy to math or physics is a false 
analogy.  In math, in fact, it is a frequently used (and occasionally 
debated) proof technique to assume the negation of the statement and show 
it leads to a contradiction with some previous proven truth.  So the 
consequences of the statement in question matter: if they produce hopeless 
contradiction then one has shown that claim to be false and its negation 
thus true.  Extending this to a moral argument, if one shows that a 
seemingly moral claim leads to an immoral result then the original claim is 
immoral under the same principle. ﻿
